Men in Equatorial Guinea do not believe in women’s financial independence; hence, this discourages some widows from marrying again.

When she is married again, a widow is considered socially-less honored than a woman living with an unmarried man.

Achieving Social Justice for Wives and Widows: Post-divorce Matters

Wives or widows may complain of mistreatment or unfairness after a divorce. Ex parte divorces allow swift divorces with no discussion or deliberation of rulings. It devalues the wife’s contribution to the marriage.

Men view divorces with no contributions as a trivial issue, avoid court proceedings and use family contacts to arrange for child support or none. Many maintain that divorces with contributions are less dangerous to social order and increase women’s social security.

Struggling for Social Justice: Good Practices and Norms for Women and Widows Rights

While laws that support women’s right to property have not been implemented at the state and federal levels neither is it enforced. A woman’s legal rights are not, thus, realized.

A widow’s property is usually inherited by a male family member of the deceased, including her children. Women are often not included in wills.

The courts are the only initiate that can recognize widows as special case and grant them legal personhood. However most states do not meet their legal obligations to ensure widows’ rights to property.
